name: 郭若妤
objective: Gamification is a technique that can stimulate users’ motivation and engagement in various non-game contexts such as education, business, health, workplace, and so on. This course is divided into two parts. The first part provides the theoretical background, consisting of the gamification definition/taxonomy, and behavioral design. In the second part of this course, students will organize a participatory design workshop to gain insights from the stakeholders to develop a gamified product, service, or system that are fun, engaging, and rewarding.
schedule:
Week	Topics
1	Course objective, structure, syllabus, and grading
2	Introduction: Why gamification 	
3	Theoretical basics	
4	Individual presentation: Case studies in game applications 	
5	PART I: Examine the real-world gamification examples
6	Discussion: Intrinsic extrinsic rewards	
7	The core drives of gamification 
8	Gamification mechanic and elements 	
9	PART II: Develop design project proposal 	
10	Discussion: Player’s journey	
11	Discussion: Player’s type
12	Group presentation 
13	YODEX young designers' exhibition 
14	Discussion: Social good and behavior change	
15	Discussion: Onboarding and offboarding
16	Discussion: Ethical issues in gamification  
17	Discussion: Reflecting on the design framework 
18	Final video and group presentation
scorePolicy:
Attitude: Punctuality & Initiative (10%), Independence (10%)
Design project capability: Execution & Analysis (15%), Innovation (15%)
Final video and presentation: 50%
materials:
Chou, Y. K. (2019). Actionable gamification: Beyond points, badges, and leaderboards. Packt Publishing Ltd.
Eyal, N. (2014). Hooked: How to build habit-forming products. Penguin.
Schell, J. (2008). The Art of Game Design: A book of lenses. CRC press.
